comments.body: A hazard of drafting in Google docs is that apparently every quotation mark ended up curly. That might be worth fixing if you have time :).
It's easy enough to fix (simple search/replace), but left them because I figured they're actually more typographically correct anyway...
I think sphinx can be configured to render these from straight quotes: http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/user/smartquotes.html

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +12,16 @@
We outline a high-level vision for how NumPy will approach handling
“duck arrays”. This is an Informational-class NEP; it doesn’t
prescribe full details for any particular implementation. In brief, we
propose developing a number of new protocols for defining

comments.body: we might as well update this :)
eh, that is when it was created... we could bump to today if you want

67 of these are `__dunder__` methods, mostly due to the arithmetic operators. 42 of these are handled with:
```
>>> not_scalar_operators = set(dir(np.ndarray)) - set(dir(np.lib.mixins.NDArrayOperatorsMixin))
>>> len(not_scalar_operators)
96
```

Leaving the remaining 25 (grouped by meaning) as:

```python
{
 '__array__',
 '__array_finalize__',
 '__array_interface__',
 '__array_prepare__',
 '__array_priority__',
 '__array_struct__',
 '__array_ufunc__',
 '__array_wrap__',

 '__bool__',
 '__index__',
 '__int__',
 '__float__',
 '__complex__',

 '__contains__',
 '__iter__',
 '__len__',
 '__getitem__',
 '__setitem__',
 '__delitem__',

 '__copy__',
 '__deepcopy__',

 '__matmul__',
 '__rmatmul__',
 '__imatmul__',

 '__setstate__',
}
```

Indeed, but the point here is just that duck arrays have a lot of stuff they have to do, so I think those dunder methods are still appropriate. (Not that it even matters that much, as the text says this is a huge underestimate anyway.)
